awd_titl_txt: CNS Core:Small: Re-thinking the Design of Data Management Software Upon the Arrival of SSDs with Built-in Transparent Compression
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is developing techniques that can improve the efficiency of data management software (e.g., database and filesystem) by leveraging new data storage hardware with built-in compression. These are disks that automatically compress data when it is written to the disk and decompresses data when it is read. This makes the disk appear larger than it really is because of the compression. For the first time, such new storage hardware decouples the logical storage space utilization efficiency from the physical storage space utilization efficiency, which creates a large but completely unexplored space for simplifying the design and implementation of data management software. This project involves developing a set of techniques to explore this new design space for simplifying mainstream data management software. In order to demonstrate and study the involved design trade-offs, this project will implement prototype key-value store and caching software, and enhance existing open-source filesystems and relational databases. 


By developing solutions to largely simplify data management software, this project could significantly contribute to improving the efficiency and cost effectiveness of future data-intensive computing infrastructure. This work can inspire broader research to fully explore the potential of leveraging new storage hardware with built-in computation capability to innovate computing system software stack. The developed source codes and experimental results will be available online for public and wide-range usage, benefiting both industrial and academic researchers. The research training to both undergraduate and graduate students will address the concerns of lacking researchers and engineers with cross-hardware/software expertise in IT and computer industries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project aims to enhance the efficiency of data management software, such as databases and file systems, by utilizing advanced storage hardware with built-in data compression capability. Data management software plays a critical role in modern digital infrastructure, enabling the organization and rapid retrieval of large amounts of information. As compression-capable storage hardware enters the commercial market, it opens new possibilities for innovation in the design and implementation of data management systems.

The project developed techniques that improve the performance and cost-efficiency of data management software when operating on this new storage hardware. These design solutions are crafted to integrate seamlessly into the existing software stack, ensuring that future systems can easily adopt compression-capable storage hardware without demanding disruptive changes. To evaluate the effectiveness of these techniques, the research team has implemented various software prototypes and performed comprehensive testing. These prototypes demonstrate the practical viability of the design solutions and provide a platform for studying potential trade-offs in performance and efficiency. The findings from this work have been published in technical papers and presented at prestigious conferences, contributing to the broader knowledge base in both academia and industry.

The research represents a significant advancement for the field, offering valuable insights and practical solutions for better utilizing compression-capable storage hardware. The adoption of these innovations by the computing and storage industry has the potential to revolutionize the sector, improving efficiency and driving down costs. These advancements are particularly important to the nation's high-tech industries, which are vital to economic growth and global competitiveness.
